focus_skills: Inference from sample statistics and margin of error
Systems of 2 linear equations in 2 variables

questions.skill: Inference from sample statistics and margin of error
questions.question: A school has 120 students in the chess club. A random sample of 40 chess club students was surveyed, and 12 reported participating in tournaments. Based on the sample, which of the following is the best estimate of the number of chess club students who participate in tournaments?
questions.explanation: The proportion in the sample is <math><mfrac><mn>12</mn><mn>40</mn></mfrac> <mo>=</mo> <mn>0.3</mn></math>. For 120 students, the estimate is <math><mn>120 </mn><mo>×</mo><mn> 0.3</mn> <mo>=</mo> <mn>36</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: To estimate a population total from a sample proportion, multiply the proportion by the population size.

questions.skill: Inference from sample statistics and margin of error
questions.question: A survey estimated that the mean time spent studying per week by students is 15 hours, with a margin of error of 2 hours. Which of the following is the most plausible conclusion?

options.A: The mean study time for all students is between 13 and 17 hours.
options.B: All students study exactly 15 hours per week.
options.C: No student studies more than 17 hours per week.
options.D: The mean study time is 17 hours.

questions.explanation: The margin of error gives a plausible range of <math><mn>15</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></math> to <math><mn>15</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></math>, or 13 to 17 hours.
questions.score_improvement_tip: The margin of error defines a range around the estimate where the true population value is likely to fall.

questions.skill: Inference from sample statistics and margin of error
questions.question: A random sample of 50 library patrons found that 20 returned books late. Based on this sample, what is the best estimate of the percentage of all library patrons who return books late? (Enter an integer.)
questions.explanation: The sample proportion is <math><mfrac><mn>20</mn><mn>50</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>0.4</mn></math>, or 40%.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Convert sample proportions to percentages by multiplying by 100 for population estimates.

questions.skill: Linear equations in 1 variable
questions.question: If <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Add 8 to both sides: <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>28</mn></math>. Divide by 4: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Isolate the variable by performing inverse operations step by step.

questions.skill: Inference from sample statistics and margin of error
questions.question: A random sample of birds in a forest showed that 25% had migrated. Which conclusion is best supported?

options.A: Exactly 25% of all birds in the forest have migrated.
options.B: The majority of birds in the forest have not migrated.
options.C: Approximately 25% of all birds in the forest have migrated.
options.D: No birds in the forest have migrated.

questions.explanation: The sample result generalizes approximately to the population, not exactly or to absolutes.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Sample statistics provide approximate inferences about populations, avoiding overgeneralizations.

questions.skill: Inference from sample statistics and margin of error
questions.question: An estimate of the mean height of trees in a park is 50 feet, with a margin of error of 4 feet. Which is the best conclusion?

options.A: All trees are between 46 and 54 feet tall.
options.B: The mean height is plausibly between 46 and 54 feet.
options.C: Most trees are exactly 50 feet tall.
options.D: No tree is taller than 54 feet.

questions.explanation: The margin applies to the mean, giving a plausible range for the population mean of <math><mn>50</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn></math> to <math><mn>50</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn></math> feet.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Distinguish between inferences about means and individual values when using margins of error.

questions.skill: Inference from sample statistics and margin of error
questions.question: A sample of 200 voters estimates 45% support a policy, with a 5% margin of error. What is the upper bound of the plausible percentage? (Enter an integer.)
questions.explanation: Upper bound is <math><mn>45</mn><mo>%</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>%</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>50</mn><mo>%</mo></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Add the margin of error to the estimate for the upper plausible value.

questions.skill: Nonlinear equations in 1 variable
questions.question: What is the larger positive solution to <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: The equation factors as <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. The solutions are 2 and 4.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Factor quadratics by finding numbers that multiply to c and add to b.

questions.skill: Right triangles and trigonometry
questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='200' height='200' viewBox='0 0 200 200' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='200' height='200' fill='white' /><defs><marker id='arrow' markerWidth='10' markerHeight='10' refX='0' refY='3' orient='auto' markerUnits='strokeWidth'><path d='M0,0 L0,6 L9,3 z' fill='#000' /></marker></defs><polygon points='40,160 40,110 160,160' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><polyline points='40,150 50,150 50,160' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><text x='25' y='140' font-family='Arial' font-size='14' text-anchor='middle'>5</text><text x='100' y='180' font-family='Arial' font-size='14' text-anchor='middle'>12</text><text x='110' y='130' font-family='Arial' font-size='14' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>?</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Right triangle with legs 5 and 12, hypotenuse labeled ?
questions.question: In the right triangle shown, what is the length of the hypotenuse?
questions.explanation: By Pythagorean theorem: <math><msqrt><mrow><msup><mn>5</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mn>12</mn><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></msqrt><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mrow><mn>25</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>144</mn></mrow></msqrt><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mn>169</mn></msqrt><mo>=</mo><mn>13</mn></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='200' height='200' viewBox='0 0 200 200' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='200' height='200' fill='white' /><polygon points='40,160 40,110 160,160' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><polyline points='40,150 50,150 50,160' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='40' y1='110' x2='160' y2='160' stroke='red' stroke-width='3' /><text x='25' y='140' font-family='Arial' font-size='14' text-anchor='middle'>5</text><text x='100' y='180' font-family='Arial' font-size='14' text-anchor='middle'>12</text><text x='110' y='130' font-family='Arial' font-size='14' fill='red' font-weight='bold'>13</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: Right triangle with legs 5 and 12, hypotenuse 13 highlighted.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Apply the Pythagorean theorem for right triangles to find missing sides.

questions.skill: Systems of 2 linear equations in 2 variables
questions.question: What is the solution to the system <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math> and <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Multiply first by 3: <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>15</mn></math>. Subtract second: <math><mn>7</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>11</mn></math>, <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>11/7</mn><mo>≈</mo><mn>1.57</mn></math>, but wait, let's calculate correctly. Actually, better: from second, <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn></math>. Substitute: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>, <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>, <math><mn>7</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>13</mn></math>, <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>13/7</mn><mo>≈</mo><mn>1.86</mn></math>, <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>13/7</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>39/7</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>28/7</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>11/7</mn><mo>≈</mo><mn>1.57</mn></math>. Wait, not matching options. Let's adjust options to fit correct calculation. Assume correct is (2,1.5), but let's make question <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3.5</mn></math>, <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2.5</mn></math>, add: <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>, <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>, <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1.5</mn></math>.
questions.question: What is the solution to the system <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3.5</mn></math> and <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2.5</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Adding the equations: <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>, <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>. Then <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3.5</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>1.5</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use addition or substitution to solve systems of linear equations.

questions.skill: Inference from sample statistics and margin of error
questions.question: A study estimated 40% of adults prefer coffee, with 4% margin of error. Which statement is correct based on the margin of error?

options.A: Exactly 4% of the sample responses were incorrect.
options.B: It is not possible that fewer than 36% of all adults prefer coffee.
options.D: It is doubtful that 45% of all adults prefer coffee.

questions.explanation: The plausible range is 36% to 44%, so 45% is outside and doubtful.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Values outside the estimate ± margin are unlikely for the population.

questions.skill: Inference from sample statistics and margin of error
questions.question: Two samples from the same population: Sample P (55% favor, margin 3.5%), Sample Q (52% favor, margin 2%). Why is P's margin larger?
questions.explanation: Larger margin typically indicates smaller sample size, as it's less representative.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Margin of error decreases with larger sample sizes.

questions.skill: Inference from sample statistics and margin of error
questions.question: In a class of 30, 40% of a random sample of 15 reported liking math. If there are 600 classes, estimate students who like math across classes. (Integer)
questions.explanation: 40% of 15 is 6 students in the sample. The estimated number per class is <math><mn>0.4</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>30</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math>. For 600 classes, the total is <math><mn>12</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>600</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>7200</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Extrapolate sample proportions to larger populations carefully.

questions.skill: Inference from sample statistics and margin of error
questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='350' height='250' viewBox='0 0 350 250' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='350' height='250' fill='white' /><defs><pattern id='grid' width='350' height='20' patternUnits='userSpaceOnUse'><path d='M 40 20 L 340 20' fill='none' stroke='#f0f0f0' stroke-width='1'/></pattern></defs><rect x='40' y='20' width='300' height='200' fill='url(#grid)' /><line x1='40' y1='220' x2='340' y2='220' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='40' y1='220' x2='40' y2='20' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><text x='35' y='225' font-family='Arial' font-size='12' text-anchor='end'>0%</text><text x='35' y='185' font-family='Arial' font-size='12' text-anchor='end'>20%</text><text x='35' y='145' font-family='Arial' font-size='12' text-anchor='end'>40%</text><text x='35' y='105' font-family='Arial' font-size='12' text-anchor='end'>60%</text><text x='35' y='65' font-family='Arial' font-size='12' text-anchor='end'>80%</text><text x='35' y='25' font-family='Arial' font-size='12' text-anchor='end'>100%</text><rect x='60' y='120' width='40' height='100' fill='#4A90E2' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' /><rect x='130' y='140' width='40' height='80' fill='#4A90E2' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' /><rect x='200' y='100' width='40' height='120' fill='#4A90E2' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' /><rect x='270' y='160' width='40' height='60' fill='#4A90E2' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' /><text x='80' y='240' font-family='Arial' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>S1</text><text x='150' y='240' font-family='Arial' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>S2</text><text x='220' y='240' font-family='Arial' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>S3</text><text x='290' y='240' font-family='Arial' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>S4</text><text x='190' y='10' font-family='Arial' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>Sample Statistics</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A bar chart comparing four samples. The y-axis represents percentages from 0% to 100%. Sample 1 is at 50%, Sample 2 is at 40%, Sample 3 is at 60%, and Sample 4 is at 30%.
questions.question: The bar chart shows the sample proportion of people favoring a new policy from four different polls. If the true population proportion is known to be <math><mn>60</mn><mo>%</mo></math>, which sample statistic is exactly equal to the population parameter?
questions.explanation: To find the sample statistic that matches the true population proportion, we look for the bar that reaches the <math><mn>60</mn><mo>%</mo></math> mark on the y-axis. Sample 3 has a height corresponding exactly to 60%.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='350' height='250' viewBox='0 0 350 250' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='350' height='250' fill='white' /><defs><pattern id='grid_ex' width='350' height='20' patternUnits='userSpaceOnUse'><path d='M 40 20 L 340 20' fill='none' stroke='#f0f0f0' stroke-width='1'/></pattern></defs><rect x='40' y='20' width='300' height='200' fill='url(#grid_ex)' /><line x1='40' y1='220' x2='340' y2='220' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='40' y1='220' x2='40' y2='20' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><text x='35' y='225' font-family='Arial' font-size='12' text-anchor='end'>0%</text><text x='35' y='105' font-family='Arial' font-size='12' text-anchor='end'>60%</text><text x='35' y='25' font-family='Arial' font-size='12' text-anchor='end'>100%</text><rect x='60' y='120' width='40' height='100' fill='#e0e0e0' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' /><rect x='130' y='140' width='40' height='80' fill='#e0e0e0' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' /><rect x='200' y='100' width='40' height='120' fill='#4CAF50' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><rect x='270' y='160' width='40' height='60' fill='#e0e0e0' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' /><line x1='40' y1='100' x2='340' y2='100' stroke='red' stroke-width='2' stroke-dasharray='5,5'/><text x='290' y='90' font-family='Arial' font-size='12' fill='red' font-weight='bold'>True Value (60%)</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The same bar chart with a horizontal red dashed line drawn at the 60% mark. Sample 3 aligns perfectly with this line and is highlighted in green.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When comparing sample statistics to a population parameter, check the y-axis values carefully to find the exact match or the closest estimate.

questions.skill: Equivalent expressions
questions.question: Which is equivalent to <math><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>11</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac></math>?
questions.explanation: Polynomial division gives quotient <math><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></math> and remainder 3, since <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn></math> and <math><mn>11</mn> <mo>-</mo> <mn>8</mn> <mo>= </mo><mn>3 </mn></math>. Thus, <math><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use polynomial division to find equivalent expressions with remainders.

questions.skill: Circles
questions.question: A circle has equation <math><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>16</mn></math>. What is the radius? (Integer)
questions.explanation: Standard form, radius is <math><msqrt><mn>16</mn></msqrt><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Identify radius from square root of constant in circle equation.

questions.skill: Probability and conditional probability
questions.question: In a group of 100 people, 60 like apples, 50 like bananas, 30 like both. What is the probability that a person likes apples given they like bananas?
questions.explanation: <math><mi>P</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>|</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>P</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>∩</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>P</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>30</mn><mn>50</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>0.6</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use conditional probability formula for given events.

questions.skill: Nonlinear functions
questions.question: The function <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn></math> has vertex at what x-value? (Integer)
questions.explanation: Vertex at <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>b</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>a</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>4</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Find parabola vertex using -b/(2a).

questions.skill: Linear inequalities in 1 or 2 variables
questions.question: Which value of <math><mi>x</mi></math> satisfies <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>></mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Subtract 2x: <math><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>></mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></math>. Subtract 1: <math><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>></mo><mi>x</mi></math>, or <math><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Remember to flip inequality sign when multiplying/dividing by negative.

questions.skill: Lines, angles, and triangles
questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='250' height='200' viewBox='0 0 250 200' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='250' height='200' fill='white' /><defs><marker id='arrow' markerWidth='10' markerHeight='10' refX='0' refY='3' orient='auto' markerUnits='strokeWidth'><path d='M0,0 L0,6 L9,3 z' fill='#000' /></marker></defs><polygon points='125,40 60,160 190,160' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='85' y1='100' x2='100' y2='100' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' transform='rotate(-60 92,100)' /><line x1='150' y1='100' x2='165' y2='100' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' transform='rotate(60 158,100)' /><path d='M 170 160 A 20 20 0 0 0 178 143' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' /><path d='M 115 58 A 20 20 0 0 0 135 58' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' /><text x='165' y='150' font-family='Arial' font-size='12' text-anchor='end'>68°</text><text x='125' y='30' font-family='Arial' font-size='14' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>x</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Triangle with base angles, one 68°, vertex angle x.
questions.question: In the triangle shown, what is the value of <math><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: The triangle is isosceles with equal side lengths, so the base angles are both 68°. The vertex angle x is <math><mn>180</mn><mo>°</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>68</mn><mo>°</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>44</mn><mo>°</mo></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='250' height='200' viewBox='0 0 250 200' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='250' height='200' fill='white' /><polygon points='125,40 60,160 190,160' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='85' y1='100' x2='100' y2='100' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' transform='rotate(-60 92,100)' /><line x1='150' y1='100' x2='165' y2='100' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' transform='rotate(60 158,100)' /><path d='M 170 160 A 20 20 0 0 0 178 143' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' /><path d='M 80 160 A 20 20 0 0 1 72 143' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' /><text x='165' y='150' font-family='Arial' font-size='12' text-anchor='end'>68°</text><text x='85' y='150' font-family='Arial' font-size='12' text-anchor='start' fill='blue' font-weight='bold'>68°</text><text x='125' y='30' font-family='Arial' font-size='14' text-anchor='middle' fill='red' font-weight='bold'>44°</text><text x='125' y='185' font-family='Arial' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle' fill='#555'>180° - (68° + 68°)</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: Isosceles triangle with base angles 68° each, vertex 44°.
questions.score_improvement_tip: In isosceles triangles, base angles are equal; use sum to find vertex.
